content.description: Knife Crack follows the full-length crack just left of the Sheath Chimney fissure.  Sharp holds and balance-tension moves to a decent topout.
content.location: The crack is located just past the Chief Block, directly left of the Chimney Sheath fissure.  The black crack contrasts starkly with the general wall.

content.description: Full Tang is the section between the Knife Crack and Boot Knife 7 feet left on the Knife Wall.  There are a number of sharp crimps, pockets, and ledges to ascend this portion of the wall.
content.location: Look for the Knife Crack just left of the fissure.  Full Tang climbs the section of wall just to the left.

content.description: Start 7 feet left of Knife Crack on crimps just below a small, right-facing hanging block.  Use flakes to gain a small seam 10 feet up, topout.
content.location: Located 7 feet left of the Knife Crack, look for a small, right-facing flake low to the ground.

content.description: **January 2022 Access update for bouldering at Catoctin** The Park requests that the following boulders be effectively closed to climbing:Hog Rock trail area: Warfare/Knifewall and Chief Block/Gateway Fin Thurmont Vista area: Sudden/SmeltedChimney Rock (only the Chimney Rock area itself – the Pyramid Boulder is outside the area of concern)Mid Atlantic Climbers asks that the local climbing community respects this request in order to protect overall access to bouldering in the Park. See here for more info.The Knife Wall is a series of low, vertical faces left of the Chief Block in Catoctin Mountain Park. Punctuated by a striking, full-length crack amidst the bone-white lichen, the Knife Wall features sharp-but-good holds for fun, easy routes up an easily protected face.Watch your fingertips - some of the holds are quite sharp.
